title: 3 Components of Main Web Application
body: Presentation (UI), Application (Logic), Data Layer (Database)

title: Separation of Concern
body: A design pattern where different parts are divided into specific sections. (easier to maintain + edit)

title: 4 Pillars of OOP
body: Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism, Abstraction

title: Elements of Chrome Dev Tools
body: Elements (HTML), Console (Execute JS), Source (Debug), Network (HTTP Monitoring), Application (Local storage, session storage, etc)

title: What is Internet Software Architecture
body: Refers to the structure design of an application

title: What is Local Storage
body: Browser based storage, persisting even if the tab is closed. Stored in key-value pairs, Capacity = 5-10MB per domain

title: Benefits of Studying Arch Patterns
body: Helps us better evaluate efficiency, robustness, security.

title: Types of Design Patterns
body: Layered (N-tiers), each layer = functional element. Microservice (components are separated and communicated via API Gateway and router). Monolithic (All composed in one place). Hexagonal (Decouple business Logic from external)

title: Local Storage vs Session Storage
body: Local storage has no expiration date while session data does expire after a certain amount of time. This amount of time can usually be chosen.

title: RESTful API
body: Representation state transfer is an arch style not a pattern for API communication

title: 5 Core Elements
body: Client server (separation of concerns), Stateless (each requires its own content), Layered System (Multilayer Client).

title: Micro SAAS via Rest
body: Light weight functionality. They are independent components, don't depend on each other. Independent components that don't directly depend on each other. Benefit: Productivity + Don't need to save.

title: HTTP Methods
body: GET (Read/Write), POST (Create new data), PUT (Update data), DELETE (Remove certain data).

title: JSON/Object
body: Converting between JSON and Objects
code:
let myJSON = JSON.stringify(myObj);
let myObj = JSON.parse(myJSON);

title: HTTP Context
body: Req = a message from client -> Server, Res = message from server -> client.

title: Status Codes
body: 200 (Okay), 201 (Created), 204 (No Content), 400 (Bad Request), 404 (Not Found), 500 (Server Error)

title: Header
body: Metadata sent with request: auth, content type

title: Body
body: The actual data being sent in a request or response

title: CRUD
body: CRUD = POST, GET, PUT, DELETE

title: NodeJS
body: A JS runtime environment that runs on the server. Allows to work backend code via JS. Advantage: Fast + efficient, large ecosystem.

title: Module
body: Reusable block of code -> http, fs, url, path

title: CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)
body: Browser security feature which prevents requests from specific domains. Usually CORS makes it so that you can only get HTTP request from your own domain.

title: AJAX
body: It allows sending http requests from within an html page without refreshing. Used for dynamic content updates. Most professional websites use this I noticed.

title: SOP (Same Origin Protocol)
body: AJAX requests must come from its own server

title: PreFlight
body: Browser sends http option before PUT/POST to see which headers are available

title: First Class Function
body: Can take other functions as arguments.

title: Call Back Function
body: Function passed to another function to return it.

title: Async, Why its Tricky
body: Operations fail or succeed we need to handle both cases, solution: return a resolve object().

title: Promises
body: Objects which represent a future result: 3 Stages: Pending, Fulfilled, Rejected

title: Common Pit Falls
body: A promise only settles once, so calling resolve again does pretty much nothing.

title: GET vs POST Size
body: GET (2048 Chars in URL), POST has no such limit in URL

title: XMLHttpRequest
body: Ready stages values 0,1,2,3,4 in this order: Unsent (created, Open() not called), Opened (open() called), Header_received (send() called), Loading (response loading), DONE (Operation Complete)

title: Web API POST Request
body: Making a POST request to send data to a server

title: Express App.js Basic Setup
body: Basic Express.js server setup

title: Math.js Import
body: Importing and using the math.js library for advanced math operations

title: Hosting ML on Azure*
body: Learned how to deploy and host machine learning models on Azure using a virtual machine. Gained experience in setting up the environment, configuring the VM, and running models in a cloud setting.

title: Intro to React*
body: Learned the basics of React, including components, props, and state. It was interesting seeing how React handles UI updates more efficiently compared to plain HTML/CSS/JS.

title: Learning TailwindCSS*
body: Learned how to use TailwindCSS. It felt very different from traditional HTML/CSS, but it was surprisingly intuitive and fast once I got used to the utility-class approach.

title: Milestone #1 Group Project Experience*
body: Milestone #1 for the group project was a great learning experience. I learned how to track API usage per user and implement safeguards to prevent excessive API calls. Instead of enforcing a strict limit like 20 calls, we chose to show the user a warning when they were using the API too frequently.
